1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

- Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Gerawan Farming Plant 2 has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Gerawan Farming Plant 2, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Gerawan Farming Plant 2 has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following processes which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name               | Process Chemical              | Process Quantity(lbs.)

Plant 2.0                    Anhydrous Ammonia               84,000

Plant 2.1                    Anhydrous Ammonia               68,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and publi

c safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

Process Chemistry



The refrigeration systems employed at Gerawan Farming Plant 2 are flooded systems. In Plant 2.0 (Process 1), high pressure liquid from high pressure receivers 1 and 2 is piped to multiple accumulators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the accumulator. Each accumulator feeds either one ceiling suspended evaporator coil, one bunker-mounted coil, or multiple bunker-mounted coils. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporator uses an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it travels back to the accumulators, through a suction return line, and into the four (4) main suction accumulators. Any remaining l

iquid falls to the bottom of the vessel and is fed by gravity into the transfer vessel. Inside the transfer vessel, the liquid rises in temperature and is returned to the high pressure receiver as high pressure liquid. From the main suction accumulator, the remaining low pressure vapor is piped to the suction inlet on the screw compressors.

 

The compressors compress the low pressure vapor, and it exits through the discharge outlet as a high pressure and high temperature vapor. The vapor is then sent to evaporative condensers where it is cooled and liquefied. The condenser uses air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver. The receiver serves as a holding tank for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side, and holds the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not operating. 



In Plant 2.1 (Process 2), high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to the subcooler and glycol chiller. The glycol chiller is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the shell of the of the chiller. The ammonia absorbs heat from glycol that runs through the tubes inside the chiller. As the liquid refrigerant absorbs heat, it vaporizes into a low temperature gas which exits the chiller and returns to the main suction accumulator. In the subcooler, high pressure liquid flows through the shell of the subcooler, and glycol flows through tubes inside the shell. The ammonia is cooled by the glycol, exits the shell as a subcooled liquid, and is piped to multiple accumulators. Each accumulator is equipped with an expansion valve which expands the high pressure liquid into a low temperature and pressure liquid as it enters the accumulator. Each accumulator feeds either two (2

) or three (3) ceiling suspended evaporator coils, or two bunker-mounted coils. The evaporators contain a set of continuous coils through which the low pressure liquid flows. Due to the low pressures and temperatures maintained in the evaporator, the liquid refrigerant absorbs a great deal of heat from the surrounding area and evaporates. To increase the rate of heat removed, the evaporator uses an electric fan to move warm air over the coils of cold liquid ammonia. Once the liquid has evaporated to form low temperature and pressure vapor, it travels back to the accumulators, through a suction return line, and into the main suction accumulator. Any remaining liquid falls to the bottom of the vessel and is fed by gravity into the transfer vessel. Inside the transfer vessel, the liquid rises in temperature and is returned to the high pressure receiver as high pressure liquid. From the main suction accumulator, the remaining low pressure vapor is piped to the suction inlet on the screw compressors.

 

The compressors compress the low pressure vapor, and it exits through the discharge outlet as a high pressure and high temperature vapor. The vapor is then sent to evaporative condensers where it is cooled and liquefied. The condenser uses air and water to cool the warm ammonia as it passes through a series of tubes within the condenser. As the cooling medium of air and water draws the heat from the vapor, the refrigerant condenses into a liquid and flows to the high pressure receiver. The receiver serves as a holding tank for the liquid refrigerant being fed to the low side, and holds the bulk of the refrigerant in the system when it is not operating. This system is also equipped with a thermosyphon vessel located between the evaporative condensers and high pressure receiver. The thermosyphon vessel supplies the screw compressor oil coolers with small amounts of high pressure liquid. As this liquid absorbs the heat from the oil, it evaporates inside the oil cooler, and

returns to the thermosyphon vessel.



Safety Systems

There is one (1) ammonia detector installed inside each of the two (2) machinery rooms. Both sensors are set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm and will activate the mechanical ventilation system and an audible alarm and strobe. Additionally, a sampling system is installed in Plant 2.1 that provides two-minute interval monitoring of the hallways outside Rooms 40-45. The sampling system is set at the California OSHA permissible exposure limit of 25 ppm, which will activate an audible alarm.



Each machinery room is equipped with two (2) roof-mounted emergency ventilation fans. In Plant 2.0, the emergency ventilation system can be controlled manually by the Hand/Auto switch located on the north wall of the machinery room, or the ON/Auto switch inside the emergency control box. In Plant 2.1, the emergency ventilation system can be controlled manually by the ON/OFF switch located in the Electrical Room, or the ON/Auto switch inside the emergency control box. 



The Emergency Control Box was installed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2 and the Fire Code at the time of construction. The control box contains three (3) valves.



Valve #1: High Side Discharge Valve

Valve #2: Low Side Discharge Valve

Valve #3: High to Low Pressure Control Valve



Opening Valve #1 will evacuate the process through the high pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #2 will evacuate the process through the low pressure side of the system. Opening Valve #3 will equalize the high and low pressure portions of the system. The Emergency Control Box is seldom used in a refrigeration system, but has been installed for rare emergency situations.



Each screw compressor has numerous safety devices to protect the compressor and the associated equipment. All ASME vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves. The high side of each system relieves at 250 psig while the low side of each system relieves at 150 psig. All pre

ssure relief valves vent to the atmosphere.



Each Main Suction Accumulator is equipped with a high level float switch that is wired to shut down the compressors in the event of a high level situation. This prevents liquid ammonia from entering the compressor.



Process Classification

Each ammonia refrigeration system at Gerawan Farming Plant 2 consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. The systems are neither interconnected nor co-located relative to each other. As such, the refrigeration systems at Gerawan Farming Plant 2 are treated as two (2) independent processes.



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Gerawan Farming Plant 2 has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration processes. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia



The ammonia refrigeration processeses at the Gerawan Farming Plant 2 facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. Both ammonia processes contain a total charge of approximately 152,000 lbs. It is extremely important that these processes are maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.



Our refrigeration personnel monitor both ammonia refrigeration processeses and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the processes are checked frequently by

one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



On June 16, 2020, Gerawan Farming Plant 2 had an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. The accident occurred at approximately 7:25 am. The accident occurred on Plant 2.1, Compressor 3, when the High Stage Suction (HSS) strainer gasket failed. Upon investigation, two of the four bolts on the strainer cap were broken.



The duration of the release was five hours. The amount of ammonia released was estimated to be 5,461 lbs. Businesses and households near the facility were instructed to shelter-in-place. Reedley Fire Department stated that there were no reported injuries or complaints over the five hours of the incident.

Within 21 minutes of the incident the local CUPA, 911, CalOES, and the National Response Center were notified. An investigation was performed and the following recommendations were made:



1. Upon investigation, one of the four bolts on the strainer cap was broken and missing for years. This was identified by APCCO (contractor) in writing in early 2020. However, Gerawan's refrigeration department had yet to act on that recommendation. Ensure to prioritize Mechanical Integrity recommendations based on severity. Critical items that could lead to accidental releases must be addressed immediately.



2. It is unknown what caused the bolts to break before and during the incident. One possibility is that the bolts were over-torqued after the strainer was cleaned in the past. The suction strainer bolts on similar compressors could also be weak. Ensure to check the suction strainer bolts on Plant 2.1 compressors. Replace any suspect bolts and torque to manufacturer's specifications.



3. Communication between Gerawan, emergency responders and contractors was good. However, the investigation team identified improvements on the following topics: 1) a

uthorization to call the hazmat team for response; 2) communication between Gerawan refrigeration personnel and other departments within the company (front office, media relations). It is recommended to review emergency response policies with Gerawan management for continuous improvement.



4. During the 2019 PHA, it was determined that Plant 2.1 was most likely built in accordance with the 1991 UMC and Fire Code based on the age of the system and lack of a diffusion tank. These codes do not contain requirements regarding ammonia detection. Fortunately, a standalone detector is located inside the machinery room and was helpful in assessing the incident. The recently published ANSI/IIAR 9-2020 is the Standard for Minimum System Safety Requirements

for Existing Closed-Circuit Ammonia Refrigeration Systems. Although facilities have nearly five years to evaluate and implement IIAR 9, consider upgrading the machinery room detection to meet IIAR 9. This includes: 1) an alarm that reports to a monitored location so that corrective action can be taken; 2) audible and visual alarms inside the room and outside of each entrance to the machinery room. See section 7.3.12 of IIAR 9 and the following blog on the topic, https://bit.ly/2BD2q3W .



5. Some documentation from Mechanical Integrity (MI) inspections included typos and unclear information. It is recommended that Gerawan personnel thoroughly reviews future documentation for accuracy. One solution is to require all MI reports include a written executive summary highlighting critical action items. Furthermore, Gerawan's Refrigeration Department should sign-off on recommendation completion along with a second sign-off by a third party (e.g. PSM Consultant).



6. The impacts of the incident were minimal without injuries, deaths, or hospitalizations on or offsite. Furthermore, no significant property damages on or offsite. However, off site receptors were Gerawan Farming Plant 2 RMP-PSM Program advised to shelter-in-place.

Therefore, an RMP Correction is required per CalARP ?2745.10.5 and RMP ?68.195. Ensure to complete an RMP Correction with both the USEPA and the CUPA within six months of the release.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Gerawan Farming Plant 2's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38 



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Gerawan Farming Plant 2 has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Gerawan Farming Plant 2 continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Gerawan Farming Plant 2's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Gerawan Farming Plant 2's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Gerawan Farming Plant 2 has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or

past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Gerawan Farming Plant 2 has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Gerawan Farming Plant 2 now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Gerawan Farming Plant 2 employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Gerawan Farming Plant 2 will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
